description.narrative: The IRRF is UNDP’s results framework to monitor and report on its achievements against the Strategic Plan 2014-2017. UNDP publishes country level IRRF results that UNDP’s projects contributed to

Adapting national and transboundary water resource management in Swaziland to manage the expected impacts of climate change.
capital of a political entity
Social Protection, Land Housing and Community Amenities - disaster prevention and preparedness
1. Feasibility Report.

comment.narrative: 2010: Feasibility Study conducted

1. 2 Water Sector Coordination quarterly meetings, facilitating dissemination of at least 4 CCA KM products; World Water Day commemoration. 2. At least 30 Community members trained on aquaculture; 30 community members trained in horticulture. 3. One (1) training workshop conducted for the TPTC Swaziland delegation; One River Basin Authorities workshop conducted for climate change adaptation in the water sector. 4. Terminal Evaluation Report for the GEF PIMS 3603 with climate change adaptation lessons. 5. Two (2) MOU/A signed with national for increased sustainability of project outcomes beyond the project life. 6. Emergency support capacities for the impacts of El Nino: Emergency water trucking and harvesting infrastructure in selected schools and health facilities.

1.The Joint Coordination structure for the Water Sector was established. The process involved drafting structural arrangement protocols for the sector. Five (5) CC-A knowledge product developed along: Sand Dams Management, Rain-water harvesting, and Climate Change Mainstreaming. Climate Change Tool-kits were developed included the Land-use Tool-kit Version 1.0. The Climate Mapper and Digital Agriculture. These products were disseminated to the national stakeholders during the 2016 World Water Day.
2. Forty-two (42) members of the Mbelebeleni community were trained in aquaculture and horticulture by the Ministry of Agriculture in collaboration with World Vision. This resulted in planting of 1,250 fruits and indigenous trees and establishment of trout fish dams,
3. One (1) training was conducted on the climate change modelling for the Usuthu, Mbuluzi and Komati River Basins and impacts of climate change at transboundary level. Sixty-one (61) participants from the five (5) River Basin Authorities were also engaged on the climate change on the same resulting in increased knowledge on the role of RBAs in integrated water resources catchment management (IRRF 2.5.2).
4. The GEF PIMS 3003 CC-A: Swaziland Terminal Evaluation was timely completed. The Sand Dams development story facilitated under the project featured in the global GEF Newsletter. Key lessons indicate the need for gender mainstreaming even in pilot projects given that their upscaling, impacts differently between men and women.
5. Two (2) MOU were signed with the Ministry of Agriculture National Agriculture Marketing Board (NAMBOARD) and the non-governmental organization World Vision. The collaboration with NAMBOARD resulted in the 12 committee members leading the conversion of 5ha of land into drip irrigation farming as well as production of vegetables for both household consumption and selling to the market. On the other hand, capacity development for conservation management will continue being stren

description.narrative: Climate change risk management measures integrated into national water and agricultural programmes and implemented in pilot projects to promote adaptation on the ground

21 Guidelines for mainstreaming climate change risks into key national policies NWP IWRMP NCCP developed toolkits on practical application of climate change response measures identified through Output 12 developed and at least five 5 targeted training courses on toolkit application delivered

comment.narrative: 21 Key national policies do not or not adequately consider climate change and inadequate knowledge on practical implementation of climate change response measures

21 Guidelines for mainstreaming climate change risks into key national policies NWP IWRMP NCCP developed toolkits on practical application of climate change response measures identified through Output 12 developed and at least five 5 targeted training courses on toolkit application delivered

211 213 The final guidelines for mainstreaming climate change and toolkits for practical implementation of climate for the water and land use sector were developed and finalised in collaboration with the key stakeholders Recommendations for Policy statements for climate change mainstreaming were developed for inclusion into the following national policies
Water sector policies IWRM Master Plan National Water Policy
National Land Policy
Review of the Environment Impact Assessment Regulatory Framework
Comprehensive Agricultural Sector Policy
In addition various tools for practical application of climate change response measures for water and land use were developed The tools included Digital agriculture amp Land use Toolkit Version 10 December 2014 The Climate Mapper CRISTAL Climate Vulnerability and Capacity Analysis Tool cvca Climate Change Monitoring Tool WEAP Mike Basin SCADA andStandard Precipitation Index 40 Upon validation of the reports stakeholders were engaged in a training on the practical use of these tools to foster understanding and technical skilling

description.narrative: Institutional capacity for climate change adaptation strengthened through the integration of climate change risks into national water resources management policies and the establishment of intersectoral coordination mechanims based on inclusive and informed national dialogue

11 Key scientific knowledge gaps on climate change impacts within the water sector defined targeted research to fill knowledge gaps carried out climate change response options identified and main findings and strategic recommendations disseminated to at least twenty 20 relevant organisations across sectors incl KOBWA MNRE MoA MoEPD MoF MoH MoPSI MTEA NCCC NDMA NMS NWA RBAs SEA SWADE SZWP TPTC

comment.narrative: 11 Information in Swaziland on climate change risks and possible impacts is scarce particularly regarding flood vulnerability groundwater potential and crop diversification options

11 Key scientific knowledge gaps on climate change impacts within the water sector defined targeted research to fill knowledge gaps carried out climate change response options identified and main findings and strategic recommendations disseminated to at least twenty 20 relevant organisations across sectors incl KOBWA MNRE MoA MoEPD MoF MoH MoPSI MTEA NCCC NDMA NMS NWA RBAs SEA SWADE SZWP TPTC

The key baseline studies and knowledge gaps on climate change impacts for the water sector were conducted and completed during the 201314 reporting period The Third National Communications to the UNFCCC for Swaziland supported by UNEP analytic base has already benefitted from the 2014 CC Vulnerability Assessment Report facilitated by the Project Information packaging is currently underway through the development of abridged versions and new products for different users in particular decision makers the various technical institutions vulnerable community members and women These will be shared with stakeholders in various platforms such as meetings public offices electronically and through the webpage The products include
Summarized versions of all the key project reports the vulnerability assessment crop diversification study groundwater study and policy and institutional dialogues report
Project Policy brief report based on report outcomes
Lessons learnt report
Technical Knowledge sharing products in both English and local language Siswati through pamphlets brochures for sand dams rainwater harvesting and ecosystem restoration
Development of a video on sand dams construction maintenance and use
Development of a scientific paper on sand dams technology for information sharing with the academia and other partners
This will increase the visibility of the project and spread the successful story of the project impacts The Outputs will also be shared in both the UNDP website and the Government DWA new project website currently being developed The targeted institutions include KOBWA MNRE MoA MoEPD MoF MoH MoPSI MTEA NCCC NDMA NMS NWA RBAs SEA SWADE SZWP TPTC Some of the products will target other stakeholders like communities and local traditional leaders

description.narrative: 12 A set of tailormade climate change response measures related to national and transboundary water management identified and integrated into at least three 3 national level policies related to water resources management eg NWP IWRMP draft National Climate Change Policy through a series of national policy dialogue workshops incl with organisations listed under Output 11 and using strategic recommendations from that output

comment.narrative: 12 Key national policies do not or not adequately consider climate change

12 A set of tailormade climate change response measures related to national and transboundary water management identified and integrated into at least three 3 national level policies related to water resources management eg NWP IWRMP draft National Climate Change Policy through a series of national policy dialogue workshops incl with organisations listed under Output 11 and using strategic recommendations from that output

121 The project has facilitated climate change issues in the water sector in overall The climate change response measures that were identified in a participatory manner involving all key stakeholders culminated into the drafting of policy statements for inclusion in the water sector related policies The scientific evidence and outputs of the project vulnerability assessments were used as a reference point in the formulation of the following policies
Final draft of the Climate Change Policy developed in 2014
Climate Change Strategy and Action Plan 20142018 incorporating adaptation measures for the water sector completed in 201314
Policy statements on climate change adaptation for inclusion in the following water sector strategic documents were developed 2003 National Water Policy and the IWRM Master Plan These statement briefs are utilized by the DWA in a review process for integration of climate change through an EU funded project The Emergency Preparedness Plans for the major dams in Swaziland Reports were produced These are currently being utilized by the DWA to inform the new country Dam Safety Regulations that are under formulation The project outputs have also been instrumental in informing the drafting of the Third National Communication to the UNFCCC and the Intended National Determined Contributions INDCs Report to be submitted to UN in October The PMU serves in the technical working group to facilitate supply of climate change adaptation and mitigation information for the water sector

description.narrative: Negotiations on transboundary water management for the Incomati Maputo and Umbeluzi river basins informed by climate change risk analysis

31 Climate change impacts on transboundary water resource management TWRM and negotiation options assessed tailormade short mid and longterm TWRM strategy paper for Swaziland developed through consultations with key stakeholders as integral part of national policy dialogue Output 12 and position paper for Swaziland TWRM negotation teams jointly developed with negotiators

comment.narrative: 31 Present water agreements on Incomati Maputo do not adequately address climate change and adaptation

31 Climate change impacts on transboundary water resource management TWRM and negotiation options assessed tailormade short mid and longterm TWRM strategy paper for Swaziland developed through consultations with key stakeholders as integral part of national policy dialogue Output 12 and position paper for Swaziland TWRM negotation teams jointly developed with negotiators

311 322 The project has continued to engage with the TPTC and negotiating bodies at national level A consensus has been reached that this component is very essential both within the country and at the transboundary level The project has facilitated the engagement of both local and international consultants to assist in developing the position and strategy paper informing the delegation to the TPTC A model for water and demand management is currently being established for the three major basins Komati Mbuluzi and Usuthu Data collection is underway among the various entities and institutions The inception phase of the study has been completed The team of consultants are currently working on the modelling of various climate change scenarios that will inform the position of the country and further inform the strategy that will focus the country on CCA IWRM as well as conducting stakeholders consultation at various levels including the transboundary levels The final outputs are expected in October 2015 upon which the engagement of the riparian countries to discuss the outcome will be solicited The process has received political support from the Minister of Natural Resources and Energy The capacity of the TPTC negotiating team will also be built through training through utilization of the project outputs like the climate change vulnerability assessment for the water sector and infrastructure

description.narrative: Strengthening Capacity for Environmental Sustainability and Climate Change.

title.narrative: Environment Sustainability & Climate Change Project Document

description.narrative: The IRRF is UNDP’s results framework to monitor and report on its achievements against the Strategic Plan 2014-2017. UNDP publishes country level IRRF results that UNDP’s projects contributed to

Total number of disaster risk reduction and/or integrated disaster risk reduction and adaptation plans, and dedicated institutional frameworks and multi-stakeholder coordination mechanisms, are in place

Number of disaster risk reduction and/or integrated disaster risk reduction and adaptation plans, and dedicated institutional frameworks and multi-stakeholder coordination mechanisms, which are gender responsive
total number of legislative or regulatory provisions for DRM (including CRM)
number of legislative or regulatory provisions for DRM (including CRM) that are effective
Capacity development through establishment of national frameworks for environment and climate change integration as well as risk mainstreaming.
capital of a political entity
Social Protection, Land Housing and Community Amenities - disaster prevention and preparedness

1. National Climate Change Strategy and Action Plan in place by 2013 2. National Climate Change Policy in place by 2014 3. Number of community resilience initaitives supported: National Disaster Simulation Excercise, World Disaster Day etc 4. Number of national capacity building intiatives for enhanced management and monitoring of natural resources.

comment.narrative: 1. Limited enabling environment for national climate change undertaking: no national frameworks or ingration of climate change into sectoral approches. 2. Disaster risk management not promoted fully: limited resources. 3. Limited capacity to manage natural resources sustainably.

1. National capacities through enhanced frameworks for climate change management: draft Climate Change Bill; National Adaptation Plan (if resources are available). 2. Sustainable Energy for ALL Investment Prospectus and Actions Agenda (IP-AA) for an engaged national stakeholders for increased uptake of renewable energy production and private sector involvement. 3. Two 'waste for jobs' pilot schemes in place. 4. Increased national and local capacities for disaster risk management: 5 local governments contingency plans; national standard operating procedures.

1. The 2015 Climate Change Policy was approved. Continued to support an enabling environment for institutionalization of climate change in the country leading to the endorsement for the development of the Climate Change Bill (IRRF 1.4.2): draft in place. Supported national participation (two national participants) to the UNFCCC COP 22, where the country promulgated the National Climate Change Policy at Marrakech, Morocco and CBD COP-MOP in Cancun Mexico (one participant). The media-connect led to establishment of a partnership to create better awareness on the SDGs and Climate Change.
The development of the National Adaptation Plan (NAP) could not be supported because of lack of resources.
2. The Sustainable Energy for ALL Investment Prospectus and Actions Agenda (IP-AA) was finalized and approved by the Cabinet and serves as a reference instrument for the development of the Renewable Energy interventions. The IP-AA is also informing the collaboration with IRENA in support to the country for the development of the Swaziland Energy Master Plan (IRRF 1.4.2)
3. The ‘waste for jobs’ pilot was secured working under the Local Development Economy initiative. Out of the 45 homeless individuals salvaging the Matsapha landfill 10 were recruited and capacitated to become waste ‘Reclaimers’ working at the Matsapha Industrial Site Landfill. These participants received training and equipment to recover material and recycle. The municipality is exploring market for the products (IRRF 1.3.2).
4. No support was provided in this regard as the CO prioritized support to the El Nino drought emergency coordination.

1. Improved waste management capacities at national and local levels: Waste Management Indaba Report dissemination: Number of Matsapha landfill Waste Reclaimers trained in waste recycling; Matsapha Town Council Waste Management Policy draft. 2. National climate change frameworks status improved: Climate Change Bill. 3. National Adaptation Plan developed

1. Improved uptake of waste management practices at local levels leading to the dissemination of the Waste Management Indaba Report, training of 37 Matsapha landfill Waste Reclaimers on waste recycling and product development. The Matsapha Town Council drafted the Waste Management Policy. 2. The National Climate Change Bill was not developed due to re-prioritization by the Ministry of Tourism and Environmental Affairs. 3. National Adaptation Plan was not developed because of lack of resources.
